conversation.content:
Wait, you're not—you're not serious. [shaky voice] Margaret, this check, it's... [pause] I can't take this from you. [hesitantly] You come in every morning for your cranberry scone and, um, we talk about your grandkids and the weather and— [overwhelmed] this is fifty thousand dollars. [gasp loudly] I mentioned the expansion thing like, what, twice? [confused] Maybe three times when I was complaining about the oven breaking?

[crying while speaking] You wrote "for someone who makes every morning brighter" on the memo line. Margaret, I just—I make pastries. [sniffle] That's all I do. [very quietly] You don't even know if I'm good at business or if I'll— [trailing off]

[laugh] Oh God, you're smiling at me like you always do when I overthink the croissant pricing. [warm] Seven years, Margaret. Seven years you've been coming here and I... [emotional] I never knew you were listening that carefully. Well, I mean, [stuttering] I-I knew you listened but not like— [pause] not like this.

[extremely happy] You believe in me. [whispered] You actually believe in my stupid little dream about the second location. [crying while speaking] I don't even know what to—how do you thank someone for changing your entire life?

subject: Your bakery counter regular surprising you with a loan to expand your business after years of daily conversations
